title: Pest Control in Your Home
author: Amber Felton, Evan Starkman

sections.heading: What Is Pest Control?
content: A kingdom of insects and small critters lives outside your home, and some of them might cause serious problems if they get indoors. Certain pests can cause property damage, infest rooms and belongings, or spread disease. Pest control includes the steps you can take, and the products or services you can use, to keep these intruders out of your home or get rid of them.

Many experts recommend a pest control method that focuses on prevention first. It’s called integrated pest management (IPM). “All pests need food, water, and shelter to survive. IPM focuses on removing these to provide long-term pest prevention,” says Molly Vaseliou, associate administrator for public affairs at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. “When using IPM, there may also be times when pesticides are needed for immediate control.”

Whether you want to keep pests out or you need to evict ones that have already moved in, you’ve got options. Here’s what you need to know about common types of pests and how to keep them at bay or banish them from your home.

IPM focuses on removing these to provide long-term pest prevention,” says Molly Vaseliou, associate administrator for public affairs at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. “When using IPM, there may also be times when pesticides are needed for immediate control.”

Whether you want to keep pests out or you need to evict ones that have already moved in, you’ve got options. Here’s what you need to know about common types of pests and how to keep them at bay or banish them from your home.

sections.heading: Types of Household Pests
content: Several types of pests can invade your home, from rodents such as mice and rats to insects such as moths, mosquitoes, and ants, to other creepy crawlies like spiders. Pests can get into your kitchen, pantry, closets, bathrooms, basements, attics, and just about anywhere else they can access.

Many come into homes and buildings through cracks and crevices in the building’s foundation or structure. Others enter through windows and doors that aren’t properly sealed. Some come in to find shelter from the cold weather, while others come inside searching for food. Some come in for both reasons.

An important part of home pest control is first to identify the type of pests in your home. There are several kinds: flying, jumping, crawling, and more. Some can destroy wood or fabrics or infest your food items. Others can bite or sting you. Some may feed on your blood. Others may leave droppings behind that, when breathed in, can cause illness. But once you find out what type of pest you have, you can learn the steps needed to get rid of them from your home.

content: The four main groups of common pests are:

Flying pests. Flying pests include various winged insects, including moths, flies, bees, wasps, hornets, yellow jackets, mosquitoes, certain types of beetles , flying ants, and termite swarmers. Flying insects come in a variety of shapes, sizes, and colors. Some sting, others bite, and some are harmless. Certain flying insects can spread certain viruses. For example, mosquitoes can spread the West Nile Virus , the Zika virus , and Malaria . Depending on where you live, you may occasionally see a bat enter your home. Bats can spread the rabies virus to people as well as pose other health risks.

Jumping pests. The most common jumping pests that can invade your home include fleas , crickets , springtails, and certain spiders. These pests are mostly harmless, though fleas can spread diseases between household pets and sometimes even humans.

Crawling or walking pests. There is a variety of crawling and walking pests, including rodents such as mice and rats, arachnoids like spiders, and then insects like millipedes, centipedes, beetles, cockroaches, ants, and various mites . Some of these pests can produce venom or be poisonous – especially for certain spiders and insects such as centipedes. Other walking insects, such as rats and mice, can leave behind droppings that can taint food and may spread diseases to humans.

sections.heading: Wood-destroying pests.
content: Wood-destroying pets can damage your home’s structure and other possessions. These pests can be hard to get rid of and often require the help of a professional pest control company. Wood-destroying pests include termites, carpenter ants , old house borers, powderpost beetles, and carpenter bees.

Some pests are easy to identify. But it can be hard to figure out a pest's exact species. For example, there are many species of beetles, and if you see a beetle in your home, it can be hard to tell one from another. The same goes for spiders. It can even be hard to tell a millipede from a centipede . Luckily, there are many resources you can use to help identify potential pests, including:
bullets: Phone apps and other internet-based systems
Books
Professional opinions
The National Pest Management Association’s PestWorld.org
The National Pesticide Information Center’s How to Identify Your Pest
Your local county extension office
Apps such as Picture Insect: Bug Identifier and Seek by iNaturalist

sections.heading: DIY Pest Control Tips
content: There are several ways to control pests at home, either in an attempt to rid your home of a current infestation problem or to prevent one from occurring.

The first step in pest control is prevention. The best way to control pests is to make your home unappealing to them. Just like us, pests need water, food, and shelter to survive, and if they can’t find these in your home, it’s likely they’ll go elsewhere.
Take these steps to put preventive pest control in action:
bullets: Pick up all food spills and crumbs right away.
Keep your counters, tables, sinks, and floors clean. Clean and dry dishes after having meals or snacks.
Clean under large kitchen appliances, such as refrigerators and stoves. Food debris can often collect in these spaces and attract pests.

Store food in containers with airtight lids or in the refrigerator. If food is stored in cardboard boxes, make sure the boxes are sealed. Cockroaches are attracted to cardboard and can get into opened boxes easily.
Keep your trash in a container with a tight lid and take out the trash often. Place outdoor trash bins as far from your house as possible.
Try to keep your home free of clutter. Piles of magazines, newspapers, and boxes can attract pests and provide a place for them to hide.
Vacuum carpets and cracks and crevices regularly.
Don’t leave pet food out overnight. Ensure kitchen counters and pantries are kept clean, and that food is stored in airtight containers.
Regularly inspect items, especially those in storage, for any sign of infestations.

content_blocks.text: There are several ways to control pests at home, either in an attempt to rid your home of a current infestation problem or to prevent one from occurring.

Vacuum carpets and cracks and crevices regularly.
Don’t leave pet food out overnight. Ensure kitchen counters and pantries are kept clean, and that food is stored in airtight containers.
Regularly inspect items, especially those in storage, for any sign of infestations.

content: Along with keeping your home clean and organized, take some other protective measures, too:

Plenty of people choose to get help from a pest-control professional, use pesticides on their own, or buy various pest-specific traps such as mouse traps and ant traps. But there are a few other steps you can take in your pest control journey, including do-it-yourself (DIY) measures.
bullets: Fix household leaks and clean up any excess moisture on counters or sinks right away. Cockroaches like water and can swim.
Fix any screens that have holes to prevent pests from entering.
Ensure that any weather stripping is replaced or repaired, and that doors and windows are sealed snugly when closed.
Check for any openings or cracks where pests may enter your house, such as behind sinks and along baseboards. If there are any, seal them.
If carpenter ants are a problem, look for damaged or wet wood and replace it. Carpenter ants are often attracted to damaged wood.
Check the foundation of your home for openings larger than one-quarter of an inch and seal them.
Keep your basements, attics, and crawl spaces dry and well-ventilated.
Have a good outdoor drainage system with good gutters to help keep water moving away from your home. Pests love moist areas, so keeping water from leaking inside your home is essential.

sections.heading: Using Pesticides
content: If you’ve already tried prevention techniques and you still have a pest problem, you may need to use some kind of pesticide to treat the area. But first, be sure that you know what kind of pest you’re trying to get rid of. For example, if you’re not sure whether you have carpenter ants or termites, get help identifying the pest from your local extension service or exterminator. Knowing what type of pest you’re dealing with will help you choose the right kind of pesticide for your problem.
Many people have successfully used certain home remedies to deter pests from entering their homes. Common pest control DIY solutions include:

These solutions are eco-friendly and will not harm the environment, you, or your household pets. Many of these solutions can be easily found in health food stores or drug marts and work on various pests. You may want to spray these oils and sprays indoors, around cracks and crevices, your windows and doors, and even outside.
bullets: Neem oil
Peppermint oil
Garlic and onion sprays
Boric acid and vinegar

sections.heading: How to choose the right pesticide
content: There are many DIY pest control solutions. Many contain ingredients you may already have lying around your home, such as soaps and oils. Others shouldn’t be too hard to find at your local grocery or convenience store. Regardless, DIY pest control solutions are safer than using harsh chemicals and pesticides.

The next step is to choose a pesticide that will work against the specific kind of pest you have and pose the least threat to your own health. Bait traps are often a good way to start. These are small plastic cups that attract pests with food mixed with an insecticide.

Using a bait trap allows you to confine the insecticide to a small area, rather than spreading it around. However, you'll still need to take care that kids and pets can't get into the bait traps. Tamper-proof bait traps are available and lower the risk of accidental exposure to the pesticide. You can buy bait traps made specifically for most household pests.

For example, if you’re not sure whether you have carpenter ants or termites, get help identifying the pest from your local extension service or exterminator. Knowing what type of pest you’re dealing with will help you choose the right kind of pesticide for your problem.
Many people have successfully used certain home remedies to deter pests from entering their homes. Common pest control DIY solutions include:

These solutions are eco-friendly and will not harm the environment, you, or your household pets. Many of these solutions can be easily found in health food stores or drug marts and work on various pests. You may want to spray these oils and sprays indoors, around cracks and crevices, your windows and doors, and even outside.
bullets: Neem oil
Peppermint oil
Garlic and onion sprays
Boric acid and vinegar

sections.heading: How to choose the right pesticide
content: There are many DIY pest control solutions. Many contain ingredients you may already have lying around your home, such as soaps and oils. Others shouldn’t be too hard to find at your local grocery or convenience store. Regardless, DIY pest control solutions are safer than using harsh chemicals and pesticides.

The next step is to choose a pesticide that will work against the specific kind of pest you have and pose the least threat to your own health. Bait traps are often a good way to start. These are small plastic cups that attract pests with food mixed with an insecticide.

Using a bait trap allows you to confine the insecticide to a small area, rather than spreading it around. However, you'll still need to take care that kids and pets can't get into the bait traps. Tamper-proof bait traps are available and lower the risk of accidental exposure to the pesticide. You can buy bait traps made specifically for most household pests.

content_blocks.text: There are many DIY pest control solutions. Many contain ingredients you may already have lying around your home, such as soaps and oils. Others shouldn’t be too hard to find at your local grocery or convenience store. Regardless, DIY pest control solutions are safer than using harsh chemicals and pesticides.

The next step is to choose a pesticide that will work against the specific kind of pest you have and pose the least threat to your own health. Bait traps are often a good way to start. These are small plastic cups that attract pests with food mixed with an insecticide.

Using a bait trap allows you to confine the insecticide to a small area, rather than spreading it around. However, you'll still need to take care that kids and pets can't get into the bait traps. Tamper-proof bait traps are available and lower the risk of accidental exposure to the pesticide. You can buy bait traps made specifically for most household pests.

content: Many of these products can and do contain harsh chemicals, so you must follow their instructions carefully and wear protective gear when handling them. You must also understand the risks that come with them. Pesticides, for example, can carry a risk of certain cancers from exposure. They may also be dangerous to household pets.
If you choose to use some type of pesticide, keep the following safety tips in mind:
bullets: Be sure the pesticide will work on the type of pest you are trying to get rid of.
Always read the label before use and follow the directions carefully. Never use more than directed.
Look for a product that is already mixed, rather than a product you have to mix yourself.
Never use a pesticide indoors that is meant to be used outside.
Apply pesticide to the smallest possible area, rather than over an entire room.
Before applying pesticide, remove children, pets, toys, and food from the area. How long should they stay out? Check the pesticide's label -- it should tell you.
Open the windows to air out the room after applying pesticides.
Wear gloves, long pants, and sleeves to protect your skin when using pesticides. Wash your clothes and take a shower after you’re done.
Only buy the amount of pesticide you need to use right away. If you have leftover pesticide, store it in the original bottle, out of the reach of children and pets.
Don’t put leftover pesticides down your drain or in the trash. Follow the label instructions to dispose of it correctly.
Never use an empty container of pesticide for any other purpose.

sections.heading: Do You Need Professional Pest Control Services?
content: Many people choose not to deal with pests on their own and instead opt for outside help from a professional pest control company or exterminator. In some cases, bringing in a professional is the best option, especially if you’re dealing with a larger-than-average infestation problem or if you’re dealing with something you can’t quite see yourself, such as bed bugs or termites.

Another reason to call a professional might be when you’re dealing with bats, since bats can often carry diseases, such as rabies and external parasites. Their poop, called guano, also can harbor spores that cause disease if breathed in. What’s more, some types of bats are protected under federal law, Vaseliou says.

In some cases, bringing in a professional is the best option, especially if you’re dealing with a larger-than-average infestation problem or if you’re dealing with something you can’t quite see yourself, such as bed bugs or termites.

Another reason to call a professional might be when you’re dealing with bats, since bats can often carry diseases, such as rabies and external parasites. Their poop, called guano, also can harbor spores that cause disease if breathed in. What’s more, some types of bats are protected under federal law, Vaseliou says.

content: “Special precautions and training are needed for handling bats and cleaning up bat guano,” she says. “Because of these considerations, there are significant advantages to using a trained professional for bat removal and management.”

Steps to remove bats from a home need to be seasonally timed, because “most states require allowing bats to raise their young prior to being excluded from a house [or] structure,” Vaseliou says. After bats are removed, it’s crucial to have a plan to seal your home so the bats can’t get back in, she adds.

sections.heading: How much do pest control services cost?
content: If you choose to not hire a professional to remove bats, Vaseliou recommends reading these tips from the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service . You can also check out Bat Conservation International , which offers tips on bat removal and prevention. The site also has info about people called wildlife rehabilitators who may be able to help remove bats humanely.
When you look into hiring a licensed and certified professional for pest control, the cost of services may vary a lot. The EPA’s Vaseliou says that these things can play a role in the price:

Type of pests. The exact type of treatment that your home needs depends on the pest. For example, getting rid of termites or bed bugs involves a different course of action and usually costs more than getting rid of cockroaches would.

How bad the infestation is and where it's located. Say you need to get rid of a large infestation inside walls of the home. That should be more expensive than a service that just involves leaving pest traps. Also, getting service for an area infested area that's hard to reach — like an attic or crawl space — could drive up the cost. These areas takes more effort to reach, and your pest control professional may need to use special equipment to get access.

Emergency service vs. regular maintenance. It can cost more to get service right away or outside of a pest control company’s regular business hours. And one-time treatments usually cost more than regular maintenance plans.

sections.heading: How to choose the right pest control services
content: Type of treatment. The treatment plan for pest control plays a role in the total cost. The price of these methods varies based on what needs, be it chemical or heat treatments, fumigation, or eco-friendly or organic products.
Take these steps before you hire a pest control company to make sure you get quality services that are safe and affordable:

Look for a license. Make sure the company has at least one licensed, certified professional who applies pesticides or directly oversees certified employees who do. Find out if the professional’s license is current, and ask if you can have a copy of it. You may be able to check a license by calling your state’s department of agriculture.

Ask if the company is bonded and insured. Bonded means the pest control company has funds to pay you back in case an employee causes any damage or loss. General liability insurance carried by a company can help protect you financially in case accidents happen while pesticides are used. Workmen’s compensation insurance also can protect you if an employee gets hurt while working in or around your home. If the company says it’s insured, ask for paper copies of the insurance.

content_blocks.text: Type of treatment. The treatment plan for pest control plays a role in the total cost. The price of these methods varies based on what needs, be it chemical or heat treatments, fumigation, or eco-friendly or organic products.
Take these steps before you hire a pest control company to make sure you get quality services that are safe and affordable:

Look for a license. Make sure the company has at least one licensed, certified professional who applies pesticides or directly oversees certified employees who do. Find out if the professional’s license is current, and ask if you can have a copy of it. You may be able to check a license by calling your state’s department of agriculture.

Ask if the company is bonded and insured. Bonded means the pest control company has funds to pay you back in case an employee causes any damage or loss. General liability insurance carried by a company can help protect you financially in case accidents happen while pesticides are used. Workmen’s compensation insurance also can protect you if an employee gets hurt while working in or around your home. If the company says it’s insured, ask for paper copies of the insurance.

sections.heading: Find out if the company has a years-long track record.
content: Check how many years it's been in business at its current address.

Request information about any pesticides to be used. The company should be willing and able to discuss the proposed treatment plan and give you copies of pesticide labels. The labels explain how the pesticide should be used, including safety measures that should be taken when using them. Tell the company you want to use the least toxic method possible to get rid of pests.

Ask what safety measures to take for children and pets. For instance, it’s important to keep children and pets away from treated areas until any pesticide spray has dried. With some treatments, the family needs to leave the home for a certain amount of time. In these cases, the EPA’s Vaseliou recommends asking the pest control company how long to stay out of the home and what steps you should take before and after the treatment to safely prepare the home for everyone. For example, ask if you’ll need to wipe down surfaces, air out rooms with ventilation, and remove or cover certain items.

sections.heading: Find out whether the company has joined a professional pest control association.
content: This can be a sign that the company is committed to doing quality work and following a code of ethics.

Check for complaints filed against the company. You might be able to find out through the Better Business Bureau, your state’s departments of agriculture, your state attorney general’s office, or the EPA.
Also, watch out for certain warning signs. Be suspicious of companies or people who:

Thorough pest control takes work. Focus on taking preventive steps to make your home as uninviting to pests as possible. And if you need professional help, do plenty of research. Make sure the company you hire is reputable and uses the safest pest control treatments available.
bullets: Don’t have a working or listed phone number.
Offer pest control as part of a package deal for services like home repair or tree trimming.
Go door to door trying to sell services to elderly or ill people who live alone. Be sure to ask for ID and check credentials.
Show up at your home to show you pests that they supposedly found in your neighborhood.
Tell you that they’ll charge you for pesticide by the gallon.
Claim that their pesticides have a secret formula that isn’t registered by the government.
Claim that a government agency has endorsed them.
Pressure you into signing a contract right away.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Pests like rodents, insects, and spiders can invade your home through cracks, doors, and windows. They might cause problems like property damage or health risks. It’s best to try to prevent pests from infesting your home. For instance, it’s important to keep your home clean and seal cracks where pests could get in. If you need to hire a professional pest control provider, make sure the company or person is licensed, has a good reputation and uses the least toxic pest control method possible.

content_blocks.text: Pests like rodents, insects, and spiders can invade your home through cracks, doors, and windows. They might cause problems like property damage or health risks. It’s best to try to prevent pests from infesting your home. For instance, it’s important to keep your home clean and seal cracks where pests could get in. If you need to hire a professional pest control provider, make sure the company or person is licensed, has a good reputation and uses the least toxic pest control method possible.

sections.heading: Pest Control FAQs
content: Look for and seal off entry points into your home such as cracks in walls and screens with holes. Also keep your home clean, and think about using eco-friendly DIY solutions.

associated_bullets: Don’t have a working or listed phone number.
Offer pest control as part of a package deal for services like home repair or tree trimming.
Go door to door trying to sell services to elderly or ill people who live alone. Be sure to ask for ID and check credentials.
Show up at your home to show you pests that they supposedly found in your neighborhood.
Tell you that they’ll charge you for pesticide by the gallon.
Claim that their pesticides have a secret formula that isn’t registered by the government.
Claim that a government agency has endorsed them.
Pressure you into signing a contract right away.

content_blocks.text: Thorough pest control takes work. Focus on taking preventive steps to make your home as uninviting to pests as possible. And if you need professional help, do plenty of research. Make sure the company you hire is reputable and uses the safest pest control treatments available.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Pests like rodents, insects, and spiders can invade your home through cracks, doors, and windows. They might cause problems like property damage or health risks. It’s best to try to prevent pests from infesting your home. For instance, it’s important to keep your home clean and seal cracks where pests could get in. If you need to hire a professional pest control provider, make sure the company or person is licensed, has a good reputation and uses the least toxic pest control method possible.

If you need to hire a professional pest control provider, make sure the company or person is licensed, has a good reputation and uses the least toxic pest control method possible.

sections.heading: Pest Control FAQs
content: Look for and seal off entry points into your home such as cracks in walls and screens with holes. Also keep your home clean, and think about using eco-friendly DIY solutions.

content_blocks.text: Look for and seal off entry points into your home such as cracks in walls and screens with holes. Also keep your home clean, and think about using eco-friendly DIY solutions.

sections.heading: What are the health risks associated with common household pests?
content: DIY pest control solutions like neem oil, peppermint oil, and garlic spray are eco-friendly and can be effective for deterring pests. To prevent infestations, seal entry points, keep your home clean and well-ventilated.

content_blocks.text: DIY pest control solutions like neem oil, peppermint oil, and garlic spray are eco-friendly and can be effective for deterring pests. To prevent infestations, seal entry points, keep your home clean and well-ventilated.

sections.heading: When should I call a professional exterminator?
content: Some pests can bite or sting. Some may feed on blood. Others may leave droppings behind that, when breathed in, can cause illness.
Call a pest control professional if you think you have a large infestation, hidden pests like bed bugs or termites, or when dealing with bats, which may carry diseases.
Yes, pest control can help you protect your home and your family’s health. If you need professional pest control, choose a licensed, certified pro who works safely.

meta_description: Many people have pests in their homes. If you're one of those people, you need to know how to control them and prevent them from occurring again. Read our guide to find out more.
